Class Animation

java.lang.Object
  Animation

public class Animation
extends java.lang.Object

Animation class returns an animated image from a sprite sheet. A sprite sheet should have a number of animations of a sprite laid out in rows and columns.

Version:
4/14/2016
Author:
Jim Stewart

Constructor Summary
Animation(java.lang.String imageName, int columns, int rows)
          To use Animation class, you must pass the name of the image (which is in your images folder) and the number of rows and columns in your sprite.

 greenfoot.GreenfootImage animate(int turnDelay)
          Use the animate image method to replace the GreenfootImage of the sprite.

Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

Constructor Detail

Animation

public Animation(java.lang.String imageName,
                 int columns,
                 int rows)
To use Animation class, you must pass the name of the image (which is in your images folder) and the number of rows and columns in your sprite. For example, to use the sprite sheet named "animation.gif" with three rows and five columns, use the following code at the beginning of your class:

Animation anim = new Animation("animation.gif", 3, 5);

Method Detail

animate

public greenfoot.GreenfootImage animate(int turnDelay)
Use the animate image method to replace the GreenfootImage of the sprite. In the act() method of your actor, simply use the following code:

setImage(anim.animate(4)); // Image will change every 4 turns.
To start with the first image, you can just same line in your constructor, as in:

public MyActor()
{
setImage(anim.animate(4));
}

animate

public greenfoot.GreenfootImage animate(int turnDelay,
                                        int startSprite,
                                        int endSprite)

getCel

public greenfoot.GreenfootImage getCel(int row,
                                       int col)
getCel method gets a particular cel based on the row or column. For example to get the cel at row 3, column 5, write:

anim.getCel(3, 5)
To start your sprite with the first cel in the animation, you can set it in your constructor as follows:
public MyActor()
{
setImage(anim.getCel(0,0));
}
